Page.title: Gii Thiu
Page.content:
Xin Cho ti tn l Lc Vn Minh, ti l mt ngi trm tnh it ni v li nhc . Cuc i i vi ti kh n c gia nh, c bn b l c tt c, cn cn c mng na ch nh. am m ln nht ca ti l lp trnh, v ti qut nh ginh c tui thanh xun theo ui am m ca mnh, t nhng dng code ca mnh ti hy vng s gp phn cho th gii tt p hn.

V Cuc Sng

Cuc sng ca ti kh n gin, ngoi lp trnh th v thi gian rnh ti thng lt eb tm hiu s tnh giang h, cc cng ng mi cng nh hackernews. vi cc hot offline, ti thch n v thch nu n, c sch. mn th tao yu thch ca ti l chy b v bi li, c l ti khng gii mn no khc :).

V ng Lc

Ti lun mun hc hi nhng iu mi m, i ln nhng vng t mi, tr nghip nhng nn vn ha mi v nm th nhng mn n mi. vi cng vic ti lun mun hon thin k nng cng nh tu duy ca mnh mi sn phm ca mnh u chm n tri tim ca ngi dng.

V Lp Trnh

Ti c mt nim am m vi lp trnh ni chung v lp trnh web ni ring. Ti thch s tin li ca PHP, yu s n nh ca java, yu s mm do ca javascript, s mnh m ca python, s n gin ca ruby. ngoi ra ti cng thch nhng front-end frameworks nh React, Angular 2, Polymer. mi trng lp trnh yu thch ca ti l Linux v cc IDE ca JetBrain.

V M Ngun M

Tt nhin ri, ti yu m ngun m v gnh c ngy trn github. Tht hnh phc khi c ng gp cho nhng d n tuyt vi nh LearnPress ..., ti sn sng tham gia vo cc d n m ngun m ngha, cho i cng l nhn li, v mt cng ng m ngn m ln mnh.

Ch Mc

di u l nhng trang eb ti thng xuyn lui ti, y nhng ngun thng tin khng l gip ti gii tr cng nh hon thin bn thn mnh hn.

  • medium tt c trn mt trang duy nht
  • wait but why nhn cc sng qua mt gc nhn mi
  • Freecodecamp mt cng ng nng ng v t v
  • hackernews tng hp tin tc cng ngh
  • TED ni chia s nhng cu chuyn ngha, nhng tng kit sut
  • Javascript sence mi kha cnh ca javascript
  • techtalk tin tc cng ngh tiwngs vit
  • toidicodedao nhng cu chuyn chn thc v cuc sng ca lp trnh vin
  • daynhauhoc din n trao i v cng ngh

Sch

ti hc c rt nhiu t nhng cun sch ny:

Lin H

hin tai ti ang sinh sng v lm vic ti H Ni.
Bn c th lin h vi ti bt c lc no qua:

  • email: luk.mink@gmail.com
  • facebook: minhlucvan3
  • twiter: @Minhlucvan
  • skype: live:minhmeo004

Rt vui khi c lm quen vi bn.

Post.title: Dependency Injection - xng sng ca Angular 2.x
Post._content:
{% asset_img "angular2-Depnedency-injction-1.png" "Angular Dependency Injection" %}

Dao ny lu bu cm o go tin qu nn blog hi b mc meo ri :), tin th ang c mt d n si Angular 2, hm nay mnh s vit mt bi v xng s ca NG2  chnh l **Dependency Injection** - **DI**. vy th  thc cht **DI** l g, chng ta hy cng tm hiu nh.
<!--more-->

nhng front-end framework hin i u hng ti xy dng cc dng dng maintainable (scaleable), predictable v testable. Cc framework hin ti  c mt cch tip cn kh ging nhau  l module ha bng **Componnent** concept ny l nn tng cho  c **React**, **Angular** v **Vue**. vi React h xy dng mt pattern tn l **Flux**  qun l dataflow, sau  cng ng pht trin v s dng rng ri cc pattern **Flux-like** nh **Redux** v **Vuex**. vi **Angular** cc nh pht trn qut nh chn mt cch tip cn phn no Phc tp hn  chnh l **Dependency Injection**  qun l dependences cho cc module ca mnh.

to be continued...

Post.title: Callback hell v nhng cch gii qut
Post.content:
Vi nhiu ngi mi lm vic vi JS th callback ng l mt ci g nguy him, thc s l nh vy! nu c mt vi tc v bt ng b ci ny ln lt thc hin tip sau ci kia m bn vit khng cn th th ci m bn to ra chnh l mt call back hell.

v d ti cn lm 4 tc v (bt ng b ) ln lt sau vi ny tip sau ci kia, cch vit nh sau chnh l callback hell

khi cn phi ni nhiu on code trn ng l shit code th thit ri, kh c kh maintain nu v tnh c c th cng ch th hiu l on ny lm mc ch g, vy c cch no gii qut vn ny khng?

Water Fall callback

cch du tin ti ngh n chnh l Water Fall callback, n gin l chia callback ra nhiu hm ri ln luwowit ci trc gi ci sau .

cch ny ch l mt cch vit khc so vi hell n trn tuy l c clear hn oi cht nhng xem ra vn khng ci thin nhiu v mt maintain code sau ny.

Promisse

Promisse l mt cch kh trit x l Callback hell, mt promisse s nh ngha mt tc v bt ng b vi hai phng thc c bn l resolve docs (hay fullfill ) bo tc v thnh cng ``reject` var then thc hin tc v tip theo ch tc v tht bi.

ta s x l 4 tc v trn vi promisse nh sau:

c v hi di dng ngh , nhng thay vo ta s c mt code flow cc k r rng ta s d dng debug cng nh ddowcj on code ny, n s i 500ms ri log ra task 1 sau i 600ms ri log ra task 2 v.v thc s vn Callback hell c gii qut. nhng vn l c php hi di dng mt cht, nhng nh pht trin JavaScript cng nhn ra iu ny v a ra nhng ci tin ln l generater function phin bn ES6 v async/await vi ES6+

generater function

nu bn mun hiu r hn v generater function mi c qua bi vit ny ca ti.

vi gi php ny code ca chng ta s d nhn hn kh nhiu, ni mt cch d hiu y nh mt cch pause hm li v resume li sau mi ln goi next, y qu thc l mt chc nng mnh m khng ch vi

y l mt tnh nng ca ES6 nn mnh s dng c php ES6 lun nh.

kh l gn g nhng vn cha phi s mt, xin trn trn gii thiu async/await

async/await

y l mt tnh nng mi ca ES7, khng cn phi ni nhiu lm g on code sau s ni ln tt c

trn y mnh gii thiu mi vi cch c bn gii quyt callback hell, hy vng gip ch c cho ai cn.

@minhlucvan

Post.title: Bn  thc s hiu generator function?
Post.content:
Hello anh em, hnh nh blog cha c bi vit no v #ES6 c hm nay mnh s qut nh vit v generator function v thnh tht m ni mnh cng cha thc s hiu thng ny lm :3, tin y mnh s gii thiu mt s ng dng cng nh tim nng ca tnh nng ny trong cc tc vu thc t.

ci nhn u tin

Mt trong nhng tnh nng mnh thy t v nht trong ES6 - ECMAScript 2015 chnh l generator function, khi lt qua cc tnh nng ca ES6 v bt gp tnh nng ny suy ngh u tin trong u mnh chnh l

ci WTF g th, bc Allen Wirfs-Brock ng l rnh ri, ti sao li sng to ra ci th ny trong khi callback vi promisse l lm async tt ri, iteritor th for vi while l c, ci my pht in ny ch phi l b i hay sao. trong khi tnh hnh tnh hnh giang h ang lon tin phn tm nh nh ny bt hc c ci g thi hay ci :(

hm nay do qua mt vng google thy ci th b i ny cng li hi ra pht. tm hiu ti sao li c ci ny mnh s i t n tng ca n, iterator.

Iterator

Iterator chnh l th m ai cng dng nhng khng phi ai cng bit n n (ng tin n la y ), cng ging trong cc ngn ng khc iterator l mt i tng dng truy cp vo mt dy cc phn t, mi ln n s tr li ph t tip theo trong dy v gi c t t duyt mi ln n c gi n. javascript iterator l mt i tng cung cp phng thc next() tr li mt i tng gm hai thuc tnh l done kim tra xem dy duyt ht cha v value ga tr phn t tip theo trong dy.

Mt khi c khi to chng ta c th gi next duyt qua thng tip theo.

Thy quen quen cha no? chun cm m nu ri, y chnh chnh l cha ca function * ch g na .

Generator

Iterator l mt pattern thc s hu dng nhng kh lt lo trong ci t v khng d dng maintain c cc trng ti ca n, n y mi thy ng l JS ang thiu mt c php chun cho pattrens ny n khai thc ht tim nng ca n, v , vng xin trn trng gii thiu Generator function cn c bit n vi bit danh function * hay yield function:

c th hiu generator l mt loi function to ra iterator, mt function c gi l generator nu bn trong c cha mt hay nhiu biu thc yield v c khai bo bng t kha function *:

nu trong function * c nhiu gi tr yield th mi ln gi next() biu thc yield tip theo s c thc hin, ging nh l hm b ng bng li ch ln gi next tip theo vy. s dng ci ny m trn lan th c th dn n kh debug v qun l state, hy th tng tng trong hm ca bn c vi lnh lp, vi lnh r nhanh v vi ci yield th

Built-in iterables

Cn nh trn mnh ni l bn dng iterator ri khng , khng ng u nh, bn khng ch dng ri m cn dng n hng ngy na. cc i tng trong javavascript nh String, Array, TypedArray, Map v Set u c built-in iterables duyt cc phn t, bi v prototype ca cc i tng ny u c phng thc Symbol.iterator.

cc biu thc vi iterables

mt vi biu thc thao tc vi iterator bao gm vng lp for-of, spread operator, yield, v destructuring assignment.

yield*

cng nh function * ni chung l thng no c c thm cai ""* l nh cm c trong tay ri c n tay ai ngi pht thi . biu thc yield nhn vo mt iterator khc hoc mt mng khi chy n n s ln lt chy qua cc gi tr ca yield* ri mi ti cc yield tip theo.

ni nm na th n c v ging vi callback .

Kt Lun

thi thay cho li kt mnh xin a ra mt s ng dng thc t ca thng ny nh:

1Async / Await

bn nghe n async/await cha, nu cha th hy tp lm qun i v tnh nng ny s c a vo ES7 y, v tin mnh i, n thc s ng ng tin bt go y:

code ca bn t th ny

s bin thnh th ny:

mt cht tng tc

mt trong nhng im th v ca generator l hm next c th nhn li mt i s qut nh nn lm g tip theo, bn s thch v d ny cho m xem :

Generator + Promise

mt s kt hp hon ho, c l no 2 th ny sinh ra ginh co nhau:

Observables v cn nhiu na

Post.title: [BOOK] c ph cng Tony - ly c ph m   hng v cuc sng
Post._content:
{% asset_img "reasons-to-drink-coffee-daily.jpg" "c ph cng Tony" %}

thc tnh m ni mnh khng my khi c sch ca cc tc gi vit Nam khng phi v snh ngoi g u nhng thc s my qun mnh c qua u khng  kin nhn c ht 10 trang u c :(, nhng do ny thy qun sch mi ca dng [Tony](http://tuoitre.vn/tin/van-hoa-giai-tri/20150115/tony-cu-an-danh-di-vay/699069.html) hot qu nn t m c th. vi hiu bit su rng, nhn quan tinh t v ging vn cun ht cun sch  ht hn mnh ngy t nhng trang u tin.

<!--more-->

![](ca-phe-cung-tony-buoi-sang-review.jpg)

C ph cng Tony l s tp hp cc bi vit trn trng mng x hi ca tc gi Tony Bui Sng (TnBS) v nhng bi hc, cu chuyn anh  tri nghim trong cuc sng.  c th l cch anh chia s vi cc bn tr v nhng chuyn to tt nh khi nghip,o c kinh doanh, hc tp n nhng vic nh nht nh n mc, giao tip, v sinh c th sao cho vn minh, lch s. Hay ch n gin thut li nhng tri nghim thc t ca anh trong qu trnh sng, kinh doanh  trong v ngoi nc.

Nu bn no khng c iu kin mua sch c th c bn mm ti [y](http://www.taisachhay.com/2015/05/ca-phe-cung-tony-tony-buoi-sang-pdf-prc-epub-mp3.html) hoc nghe bn  audio ti [y](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQBibQWDZ38) nhng tuyt vi nht vn l c bn in va hay va  ng h tc gi Tony bui sng.


Sau khi c xong cun sch ny ln u cm gic u tin n vi mnh l c phn tic nui v mnh  c qu nhanh m khng hiu ht c thng cc ip m tc gi mun truyn ti, cng phi thi ai bo vit hay qu lm chi ch mun c ngu ngin cho bng ht th thi khng cn thi gian u m suy ngm thng ip ca tc gi :D, Thi th c li ln na cho c chc. sau khi c nhng mu chuyn trong ny mi ngi s thy mt phn bn thn trong , v s rt ra c nhng bi hc cho ring mnh. Ring bn thn mnh thy rt n tng vi mt s toppic.

![](images.jpeg)
u tin  l **chuyn gio dc** tuy khng c cu chuyn no n thun ni v chuyn gio dc nhng hnh nh mu chuyn no cng c lin quan n toppic ny, tc gi ch ra s khc bit gia hai nn gio dc phng ng v phng Ty khng ch l vic hc  trng m ngay c quan nim nui dy con ci. y nh l cn nguyn ca rt nhiu th, t vic k nng sng, tnh sng to n nhng vic nh nht nh tranh lun, v sinh c nhn Ty u n dt Ta.

![](clean-up-after-youself.jpg)
Ri **Chuyn v sinh**  tng nh m khng h nh, no l mc   mi, chuyn giy tt , tm gi di ging vn d dm dc xong ci ri git mnh thon tht chi tc ga, ng ny theo di mnh hay sao  nh sao my chuyn ny m ng cng bit l sao :D.  tin topic ny nhc lun **chuyn "clean up after yourself"** nhiu khi mnh cng khng   c lm xong ri b y khng sp xp mi th nh ban u, ln ri khng c ai i dn cho na u.

![](argument.jpeg)

Post.title: Javascript module pattern - vit JS phong cch hng m un
Post.content:
Im a massive fan of JavaScripts Module Pattern and Id like to share some use cases and differences in the pattern, and why theyre important. The Module Pattern is what wed call a design pattern,and its extremely useful for a vast amount of reasons. My main attraction to the Module Pattern (and its variant, the Revealing Module Pattern) is it makes scoping a breeze and doesnt overcomplicate program design.

It also keeps things very simple and easy to read and use, uses Objects in a very nice way, and doesnt bloat your code with repetitive this and prototype declarations. I thought Id share some insight as to the awesome parts of the Module, and how you can master it, its variants and features

Creating a Module

To understand what a Module can give you, youll need to understand what the following function concept does:

It declares a function, which then calls itself immediately. These are also known as Immediately-Invoked-Function-Expressions, in which the function creates new scope and creates privacy. JavaScript doesnt have privacy, but creating new scope emulates this when we wrap all our function logic inside them. The idea then is to return only the parts we need, leaving the other code out of the global scope.

After creating new scope, we need to namespace our code so that we can access any methods we return. Lets create a namespace for our anonymous Module.

We then have Module declared in the global scope, which means we can call it wherever we like, and even pass it into another Module.

Private methods

Youll see and hear a lot about private methods in JavaScript. But Javascript doesnt strictly have private methods, but we can create a working equivalent.

What are private methods you might be asking? Private methods are anything you dont want users/devs/hackers to be able to see/call outside the scope theyre in. We might be making server calls and posting sensitive data, we dont want to expose those functions publicly, they could post anything back then and take advantage of our code. So we can create closure and be more sensible (as best as we can with JavaScript) at protecting our code. Its not all about protection however, there are also naming conflicts. I bet when you first started out writing jQuery/JavaScript, that you dumped all your code in one file and it was just function, function, function. Little did you know these were all global, and you probably suffered the consequence at some point. If so, youll learn why, and what to do to change it.

So lets use our newly created Module scope to make our methods inaccessible outside of that scope. For beginners to the Module Pattern, this example will help understand how a private method would be defined:

The above example declares our function privateMethod, which is locally declared inside the new scope. If we were to attempt calling it anywhere outside of our module, well get an error thrown and our JavaScript program will break! We dont want anyone to be able to call our methods, especially ones that might manipulate data and go back and forth to a server.

Understanding return

Typical Modules will use return and return an Object to the Module, to which the methods bound to the Object will be accessible from the Modules namespace.

A real light example of returning an Object with a function as a property:

As were returning an Object Literal, we can call them exactly like Object Literals:

For those who havent used the Object Literal syntax before, a standard Object Literal could look something like this:

But the issue with Object Literals is the pattern can be abused. Methods intended to be private will be accessible by users because they are part of the Object. This is where the Module comes in to save us, by allowing us to define all our private stuff locally and only return the good parts.

Lets look at a more Object Literal syntax, and a perfectly good Module Pattern and the return keywords role. Usually a Module will return an Object, but how that Object is defined and constructed is totally up to you. Depending on the project and the role/setup of the code, I may use one of a few syntaxes.

Anonymous Object Literal return

One of the easiest patterns is the same as weve declared above, the Object has no name declared locally, we just return an Object and thats it:

Locally scoped Object Literal

Local scope means a variable/function declared inside a scope. On the Conditionizr project, we use a locally scoped namespace as the file is over 100 lines, so its good to be able to see what are the public and private methods without checking the return statement. In this sense, its much easier to see what is public, because theyll have a locally scoped namespace attached:

Youll then see on the last line inside the Module that myObject is returned. Our global Module doesnt care that the locally scoped Object has a name, well only get the actual Object sent back, not the name. It offers for better code management.

Stacked locally scoped Object Literal

This is pretty much identical as the previous example, but uses the traditional single Object Literal notation:

I prefer the second approach we looked at, the Locally scoped Object Literal. Because here, we have to declare other functions before we use them (you should do this, using function myFunction () {} hoists your functions and can cause issues when used incorrectly). Using var myFunction = function () {}; syntax lets us not worry about this, as well declare them all before we use them, this also makes debugging easier as the JavaScript interpreter will render our code in the order we declare, rather than hoisting function declarations. I also dont like this approach so much, because the stacking method can often get verbose looking, and there is no obvious locally scoped Object namespace for me to bolt public methods onto.

Revealing Module Pattern

Weve looked at the Module, and theres a really neat variant which is deemed the revealing pattern, in which we reveal public pointers to methods inside the Modules scope. This again, can create a really nice code management system in which you can clearly see and define which methods are shipped back to the Module:

prefer the second approach we looked at, the Locally scoped Object Literal. Because here, we have to declare other functions before we use them (you should do this, using function myFunction () {} hoists your functions and can cause issues when used incorrectly). Using var myFunction = function () {}; syntax lets us not worry about this, as well declare them all before we use them, this also makes debugging easier as the JavaScript interpreter will render our code in the order we declare, rather than hoisting function declarations. I also dont like this approach so much, because the stacking method can often get verbose looking, and there is no obvious locally scoped Object namespace for me to bolt public methods onto.

Revealing Module Pattern

Weve looked at the Module, and theres a really neat variant which is deemed the revealing pattern, in which we reveal public pointers to methods inside the Modules scope. This again, can create a really nice code management system in which you can clearly see and define which methods are shipped back to the Module:

I really like the above syntax, as its very declarative. For bigger JavaScript Modules this pattern helps out a lot more, using a standard Module Pattern can get out of control depending on the syntax you go for and how you structure your code.

Accessing Private Methods

You might be thinking at some stage during this article, So if I make some methods private, how can I call them?. This is where JavaScript becomes even more awesome, and allows us to actually invoke private functions via our public methods. Observe:

Youre not just limited to methods, though. Youve access to Objects, Arrays, anything:

Augmenting Modules

So far weve created a nice Module, and returned an Object. But what if we wanted to extend our Module, and include another smaller Module, which extends our original Module?

Lets assume the following code:

Lets imagine its part of our application, but by design weve decided to not include something into the core of our application, so we could include it as a standalone Module, creating an extension.

So far our Object for Module would look like:

But what if I want to add our Module extension, so it ends up with another public method, maybe like this:

A third method is now available, but how do we manage it? Lets create an aptly named ModuleTwo, and pass in our Module namespace, which gives us access to our Object to extend:

We could then create another method inside this module, have all the benefits of private scoping/functionality and then return our extension method. My pseudo code could look like this:

Module gets passed into ModuleTwo, an extension method is added and then returned again. Our Object is getting thrown about, but thats the flexibility of JavaScript

I can then see (through something like Chromes Dev Tools) that my initial Module now has a third property:

Another hint here, youll notice Ive passed in Module || {} into my second ModuleTwo, this is incase Module is undefined - we dont want to cause errors now do we . What this does is instantiate a new Object, and bind our extension method to it, and return it.

Private Naming Conventions

I personally love the Revealing Module Pattern, and as such, I have many functions dotting around my code that visually are all declared the same, and look the same when Im scanning around. I sometimes create a locally scoped Object, but sometimes dont. When I dont, how can I distinguish between private variables/methods? The _ character! Youve probably seen this dotted around the web, and now you know why we do it:

source: https://toddmotto.com

I personally love the Revealing Module Pattern, and as such, I have many functions dotting around my code that visually are all declared the same, and look the same when Im scanning around. I sometimes create a locally scoped Object, but sometimes dont. When I dont, how can I distinguish between private variables/methods? The _ character! Youve probably seen this dotted around the web, and now you know why we do it:

source: https://toddmotto.com

Post.title: Mt button tr gi 300 triu  - Ci nhn khc v UI v chc nng
Post._content:
![ ](/image/posts/Mot-button-tri-gia-300-trieu-do-Cai-nhin-khac-ve-UI-va-chuc-nang/1.jpg) ### ngy xa ngy xa c mt trang web bn hng... Cu chuyn ca chng ta bt u chc nng Thanh ton, khi ngi dng cho ht hng vo gi, mt form nho nh xinh xinh hin ra, vi 2 trng username v password, 2 nt Login v Register, mt link Qun mt khu. Th nhng, chnh ci form be b xinh xinh ny gy thit hi n 300.000.000$/nm cho trang web bn hng. ![ ](2.jpg) Vn ch, ngi dng phi ng nhp trc khi mun thanh ton. i lp trnh ngh rng Ch cn ng k ti khon, thng tin ngi dng c th c lu li, nhng ln sau h khng cn nhp a ch, thng tin thanh ton na. Ngi dng tit kim c thi gian, web cng khuyn khch c ngi dng quay li mua hng, hai bn cng c li cn g?. ### L lp trnh vin lun ngh rng mnh hiu ngi dng i ng UI/UX lm mt cuc th nghim, a tin cho ngi dng h thc hin qu trnh mua hng thanh ton. i vi nhng khch hng mi ca trang web, h pht hin ra mt iu: **ngi dng rt ght vic ng k**, vi suy ngh Mnh mun mua hng, ch khng phi mun ng k ng kic g c. Cha k, ngi dng cn s b mt thng tin c nhn, b gi mail spam hp th. Vi nhng ngi dng quay li ln 2,3 i tng m developer nhm ti, tnh cnh cng chng kh hn. H khng nh c username/mt khu ca mnh. Mc d chc nng Qun password vn hot ng, n tn 160.000 ngi dng chc nng ny mi ngy, **75% trong s khng tip tc qu trnh thanh ton sau khi request mt khu**. ![ ](3.jpg) Chic form nho nh xinh xinh kia, ha ra li l th ngn cn ngi dng mua hng rt nhiu ngi dng. Th mi bit, developer lc no cng ngh mnh hiu c ngi dng, nhng tht ra khng phi vy. ### Chic button tr gi 300 triu la i ng designer gii quyt vn ny mt cch v cng n gin. H b i nt Register, thay vo bng nt Continue v dng ch Bn khng cn ng k, hy bm nt Continue thanh ton. thanh ton nhanh hn nhng ln sau, bn c th ng k mt ti khon vo lc thanh ton. Kt qu: Lng thanh ton ca khch hng tng ln n **45%**. Sau thng u tin, doanh s tng **15.000.000$**. Sau nm u tin, thu nhp ca web tng n tn 300 triu la. Tt c nhng vic m h lm l g? Ch l thay **mt button** m thi. ![ ](4.jpg) ### Mt ci nhn khc v UI/UX v chc nng Mt s bn cn nhm ln v hai khi nim ny, nn mnh xin a ra mt khi nim tng qut: - **UI (User Interface) Giao din ngi dng**: y l nhng g ngi dng nhn thy, tng tc c (Form, button, website). - **UX (User Experience) Tri nghim ngi dng**: y l nhng g ngi dng tri nghim, bao gm cm xc, suy ngh, qu trnh. UI ch l mt phn ca UX. VD nh khi bn mua hng trn tiki. Cc trang web thanh ton, web mua hng chnh l UI. Qu trnh mua hng/nhn hng, s thoi mi khi thanh ton, s h tr ca Tiki vi khch hng chnh l UX. Trong cu chuyn trn, bng cch thay i UI (Thay mt button), h trc tip ci thin UX (Thay i tri nghim mua hng, mua nhanh hn, khng cn ng k), t lm tng doanh s bn hng. ![ ](5.jpg) Hn nhiu bn lp trnh vin vn cn suy ngh: Chc nng mi l quan trng, cn my th ruiiii bu nh giao din th lm th no cng c (Mt phn chc l do lc mi hc lp trnh ton phi vit chng trnh Console, trc y mnh cng vy). y l mt suy ngh hon ton sai lm. Nu ch vit vi tool n gin cho chnh mnh hoc bn b xi th ng l giao din khng quan trng. Nhng nu to ra sn phm, hng ti ngi dng, th UI/UX l nhng th quan trng nht nh, c khi hn c chc nng. Nu khng tin, bn hy th c **The Inmates Are Running the Asylum** cun thnh kinh ca dn thit k UI/UX, hiu r hn v tm quan trng ca hai th ny. Hy nh mt iu mnh mun ni qua cu chuyn ny: **i khi ch mt button nho nh li c gi tr n 300 triu y**.

 cm nhn

bt k mt sn phm cng ngh no cng u hng n mc ch phc v ngi dng, ng trn gc ngi lm k thut nhiu lc developer thng b bnh "**trung tm v tr**" mc nh coi khch hng v tr ca mnh c s thch, hiu cng ngh nh mnh hc i khi c tnh chn nhng th l hoc th hin bn thn, iu thc s ti t nu c c gi ci suy ngh ch quan rng "**khch hng nh ging mnh**" v "**ta y hiu khch hng**" nh vy s ch dn n mt kt cc l sn phm build ra s ch c dev - team s dng c thi :D my nng tr li y cn cn ca ca c nn cng nghp phn mm dang nghin dn v pha u cui - pha ngi dng. mt sn phm c chc nng tt nhng tri nghim ti cha chc c ngi dng la chn thay vo h sn sng la chn sn phm khc t chc nng hn nhng to c mt tri nghim tt hn. **UX - WIN** :cherry_blossom: :sunflower: :bouquet: UX cng l mt mn khoa hc v con ngi, nn r rng my bc dev khng th ch ngi code ri vnh mt ln rng ta y hiu ngi dng, rng ngi dng thch mu ny khng thch lm th n tt c u cn a ln bn cn. th mi sinh ra ci gi l kho st ngi dng. ch ni u xa chnh nhng ng ln nh google, facebook cng hng ngy hng gi thc hin nhng cuc kho st ngm nh vy. chn c mu link nh hin ti google th nghip hng trm sc thi mu khc nhau v chn ra mu link c t l ngi click cao nht :mask:. bi vit t [techtalk.vn](http://techtalk.vn) link bi vit gc : http://techtalk.vn/mot-button-tri-gia-300-trieu-do-cai-nhin-khac-ve-ui-va-chuc-nang.html

Post.content:
ngy xa ngy xa c mt trang web bn hng

Cu chuyn ca chng ta bt u chc nng Thanh ton, khi ngi dng cho ht hng vo gi, mt form nho nh xinh xinh hin ra, vi 2 trng username v password, 2 nt Login v Register, mt link Qun mt khu. Th nhng, chnh ci form be b xinh xinh ny gy thit hi n 300.000.000$/nm cho trang web bn hng.

Vn ch, ngi dng phi ng nhp trc khi mun thanh ton. i lp trnh ngh rng Ch cn ng k ti khon, thng tin ngi dng c th c lu li, nhng ln sau h khng cn nhp a ch, thng tin thanh ton na. Ngi dng tit kim c thi gian, web cng khuyn khch c ngi dng quay li mua hng, hai bn cng c li cn g?.

L lp trnh vin lun ngh rng mnh hiu ngi dng

i ng UI/UX lm mt cuc th nghim, a tin cho ngi dng h thc hin qu trnh mua hng thanh ton. i vi nhng khch hng mi ca trang web, h pht hin ra mt iu: ngi dng rt ght vic ng k, vi suy ngh Mnh mun mua hng, ch khng phi mun ng k ng kic g c. Cha k, ngi dng cn s b mt thng tin c nhn, b gi mail spam hp th.

Vi nhng ngi dng quay li ln 2,3 i tng m developer nhm ti, tnh cnh cng chng kh hn. H khng nh c username/mt khu ca mnh. Mc d chc nng Qun password vn hot ng, n tn 160.000 ngi dng chc nng ny mi ngy, 75% trong s khng tip tc qu trnh thanh ton sau khi request mt khu.

Chic form nho nh xinh xinh kia, ha ra li l th ngn cn ngi dng mua hng rt nhiu ngi dng. Th mi bit, developer lc no cng ngh mnh hiu c ngi dng, nhng tht ra khng phi vy.

Chic button tr gi 300 triu la

i ng designer gii quyt vn ny mt cch v cng n gin. H b i nt Register, thay vo bng nt Continue v dng ch Bn khng cn ng k, hy bm nt Continue thanh ton. thanh ton nhanh hn nhng ln sau, bn c th ng k mt ti khon vo lc thanh ton.

Kt qu: Lng thanh ton ca khch hng tng ln n 45%. Sau thng u tin, doanh s tng 15.000.000$. Sau nm u tin, thu nhp ca web tng n tn 300 triu la. Tt c nhng vic m h lm l g? Ch l thay mt button m thi.

Mt ci nhn khc v UI/UX v chc nng

Mt s bn cn nhm ln v hai khi nim ny, nn mnh xin a ra mt khi nim tng qut:

  • UI (User Interface) Giao din ngi dng: y l nhng g ngi dng nhn thy, tng tc c (Form, button, website).
  • UX (User Experience) Tri nghim ngi dng: y l nhng g ngi dng tri nghim, bao gm cm xc, suy ngh, qu trnh. UI ch l mt phn ca UX. VD nh khi bn mua hng trn tiki. Cc trang web thanh ton, web mua hng chnh l UI. Qu trnh mua hng/nhn hng, s thoi mi khi thanh ton, s h tr ca Tiki vi khch hng chnh l UX.

Trong cu chuyn trn, bng cch thay i UI (Thay mt button), h trc tip ci thin UX (Thay i tri nghim mua hng, mua nhanh hn, khng cn ng k), t lm tng doanh s bn hng.

Hn nhiu bn lp trnh vin vn cn suy ngh: Chc nng mi l quan trng, cn my th ruiiii bu nh giao din th lm th no cng c (Mt phn chc l do lc mi hc lp trnh ton phi vit chng trnh Console, trc y mnh cng vy). y l mt suy ngh hon ton sai lm.

Nu ch vit vi tool n gin cho chnh mnh hoc bn b xi th ng l giao din khng quan trng. Nhng nu to ra sn phm, hng ti ngi dng, th UI/UX l nhng th quan trng nht nh, c khi hn c chc nng.

Nu khng tin, bn hy th c The Inmates Are Running the Asylum cun thnh kinh ca dn thit k UI/UX, hiu r hn v tm quan trng ca hai th ny. Hy nh mt iu mnh mun ni qua cu chuyn ny: i khi ch mt button nho nh li c gi tr n 300 triu y.

cm nhn

bt k mt sn phm cng ngh no cng u hng n mc ch phc v ngi dng, ng trn gc ngi lm k thut nhiu lc developer thng b bnh trung tm v tr mc nh coi khch hng v tr ca mnh c s thch, hiu cng ngh nh mnh hc i khi c tnh chn nhng th l hoc th hin bn thn, iu thc s ti t nu c c gi ci suy ngh ch quan rng khch hng nh ging mnh v ta y hiu khch hng nh vy s ch dn n mt kt cc l sn phm build ra s ch c dev - team s dng c thi

my nng tr li y cn cn ca ca c nn cng nghp phn mm dang nghin dn v pha u cui - pha ngi dng. mt sn phm c chc nng tt nhng tri nghim ti cha chc c ngi dng la chn thay vo h sn sng la chn sn phm khc t chc nng hn nhng to c mt tri nghim tt hn. UX - WIN

UX cng l mt mn khoa hc v con ngi, nn r rng my bc dev khng th ch ngi code ri vnh mt ln rng ta y hiu ngi dng, rng ngi dng thch mu ny khng thch lm th n tt c u cn a ln bn cn. th mi sinh ra ci gi l kho st ngi dng. ch ni u xa chnh nhng ng ln nh google, facebook cng hng ngy hng gi thc hin nhng cuc kho st ngm nh vy. chn c mu link nh hin ti google th nghip hng trm sc thi mu khc nhau v chn ra mu link c t l ngi click cao nht .

Post.title: Golang 1 - Gii thiu v Golang
Post._content:
{% asset_img "golang.png" "hello golang" %}

Al, cho ton th anh em, vn bn tnh t m yu thch nhng ci mi k t hm nay mnh s qut nh hc thm mt ngn ng backend na, sau mt hi cn nhc mnh qut nh i su hn vo  **Go** mt ngn ng pht trin bi **Google**,  m u cho lot bi ny bi vit hm nay mnh s gii thiu tng quan ca ngn ng ny cng nh nhng nhn xt ban u ca bannr thn mnh khi ln u c tip xc v tri ngim ngn ng ny,
<!--more-->

## Go l g?

**Go** hay **Golang** l mt ngn ng lp trnh bin dch, c **Googke**  thit k t cui nm 2007 v tr thnh mt ngn ng m ngn m nm 2009 vi s ng gp ca **Google** cng nh cng ng m ngun m hin nay phim bn mi nht ca **Go** ang l 1.7.

![history](history.jpg)

## Go  lm G?
c pht trin bi **Google** **Go** sinh ra  giait qut cc vn  cu **Google**:

- Nhng ng dng yu cu m rng rt ln 
- Yu cu tc  x l nhanh
- H thng phn tn
- H thng phn cng nhiu li
- network computing 


 c th gii qut tt cc vn u trn cc nh pht trin ngn ng ny  thit k nn mtj lot cc tnh nng tuyn vi.

## cc c im ngn ng

## s n gin - Less is more

nu bn mon mun mt ngun ng qun nng nh th ny: 

![](Wenger-16999.jpg)

th c l **Go** s lm bn tht vng, bi v **Go** ch c hn th ny mt cht thi:

![](01ll310.jpg)

ln c tip xc vi ngn ng ny t hn bn s ngh liu y c phi l mt bn nng cp ca ngn ng  **C**, thm ch n cn khng c hng i tng nh **C++** :D.

Khng ging nh nhng ngn ng hin i **Go** khng c khi nhim lp, i tng hay tha k, **Go** ch c mt vi tnh nng ch yu nh hm, interface, chanel, struct... vi s n gin n kh tin ca mnh **Go** li mng trong mnh sc mnh khng h thua km v tc  thc thi cng cu trc mch lc nht l vi cc h thng ln.

## B cng c built-in tuyt vi 

![](great_tools.jpg)

Song song cng pht trin cc tnh nng ngn ng cc nh pht trin **Go** cng rt cong phu trong vic pht trin cc b cng c km theo nh cng c dng lnh [**Go comand**](https://golang.org/cmd/go/) vi mt lot cc tnh nng:  **package manager**, **unit testing**, **application build**..., [**Godoc**](http://golang.org/cmd/godoc) cng c vit document, [**Gofmt**](http://golang.org/cmd/gofmt) cng c  coding covention, [**Gofix**](https://golang.org/cmd/fix/) cng c t ng fix li API ca cc phin bn trc, v cn nhiu cng c na gip cho nh pht trin d dng nht  to ra nhng sn phm c cht lng tt trong mt thi gian ngn. 

## bin dch nhanh - thun m my
![](compiler.png)

nu nh bn  s dng java hay C++ th c l cng vic nhm chn nht chnh l i chng trnh dch dnh m my (hoc bytecode) vi go thi gian  c rt ngn ng k. Ging nh C hay C++ chng trnh **Go** dc dch thng sang m my m khng cn chy qua mt my o no c iu  cng c ngha tc  tnh ton c gia tng.

## garbage collector tt

![](4TOux.png)

Mt trong nhng th **Go** lm rt tt  chnh l garbage collector, biu  trn ly t GoerCon 2016 th h  hiu uqar tuyt vi ca Go  garbage collector. nh biu  trn th garbage collector ch mt 10ms  thu hi 100GB v 12ms  thu hi 200GB Heap. tht tuyt vi ng khng no.

## nh kiu cht ch 

![](ducktyping_small.jpeg)

**Go** l mt ngn nh yu cu rt cao vi kiu d liu. v d vi kiu s ta c ``int``, ``int32``, ``int64`` nhn chung th vic ny s gip cho gim li runtime nhng i khi cng hi hoa mt vi nhng on p kiu qua li nhng nhng.

## Giao din v bao gi

![](function-composition-c.gif)

khng gip nh OOP  trong **Go** khng c class  bao gi, thay vo  l package v struct. mt lot cc bin hay hm m c tn vit hoa ch ci u s l public cn nu khng s l thuc tnh private. ngoi ra **Go** cng h tr tnh a hnh bng cch  dng interface, mt struct c th ng thi niu interfaace khc nhau.

## lp trnh ng thi

![](concurrentcy.png)

kh ging vi thread trong java nhng **Concurrentcy** trong Go r d s dng v nh nhng hn nhiu, cho php s l cc tc v ddoonhf b vi nhau. **Go** cung cp hai cch  l ``chanel`` v ``go``.

Post.title: Flux l ci qui g nh
Post._content:
{% asset_img "1.png" %}

Flux l mt kin trc cho cho font-end do Faceebook pht trin vi mc ch gii quyt chnh nhng vn  Facebook gp phi.  Kin trc ny gip qun l cc hnh ng (actions)  trng thi (state) ca ng dng mt cch ng b v d tin on (predicable), nht l vi cc ng dng c cu trc phc tp nh Facebook. bi vit ny s gii thiu v Flux cng nh cch hot ng ca n.  

<!--more-->
# Vn  m Flux gii quyt

trc tin, ta s im qua mt s vn  m Flux gii quyt. Flux l mt mu thit k  x l d liu cho ng dng, Flux v React c phat trin song song bi Facebook. V cng c thit k  s dng chung vi nhau, d vy bn hon ton c th dng Flux m khng cn n React. N c pht trin  gii qut chnh nhng vn  m Facebook ng gp phi.

![](./2.png)
Mt trong nhng vn   chnh l bug trong phn thng bo (notification). Khi bn ng nhp vo Facebook bn s nhn thy cc thng bo trn biu tng tin nhn. ri bn click vo biu tng tin nhn nhng li khng c tin nhn mi no c thng bo tin nhn mbt i, bn lt linh tinh mt lt v li c thng bo tin nhn, nhng khi click vo vn ch c tin no mi c. ch l mt vng lp ca bug m khng th gi qut vi kin trc MVC thng thng.

![](3.png)
Khng ch mt vng lp bug, m cn mt ng lp xay ra vi Facebook team khi h c fix li ny v ri mt bg mi li xut hin. mt cuc chin khng c hi kt ga dev team v bug.

vy nn Facebook mun tm cch  thot khi ci vng lun qun ny. h khng ch mun fix bux mt ln m h mun mt h thng d tin on hn v c th dm bo rng vn  c gii quyt mt cch trit .

# Bn cht ca vn 

bn cht ca vn  chnh l cch m lung d liu chy qua ng dng. 

Note: y l nhng th m ti thy c t bn rt gn m h  trnh by, nhng ti tin chc reawng kin trc thc th s khc i cht.

![](4.png)
Ta c mt vi model chu trch nhim nm gi dt ton b d liu ca ng dng  tng view  hin th ra.

bi v ngi dng tng tc thng qua view, tng view i khi cn cp nht vo models thng qua  input ca ngi dng. i khi model cng cn phi cp nht cc model khc.

quan trng nht, i khi mt vi hnh ng s ko theo mt lot cc thay i trng thi khc. c th hnh dung n nh chi bng bn tht kh  n c i ri ca bng trn bn, cng c th ra ngoi.

![](5.png)
trn thc t nhng thay i ny c th xy ra khng ng b, mt thay i c th ko theo vi thy i khc m khng nht thit xy ra ng thi. Ging nh ta nm mt r bng bn cho 2 ngi chi vy bng by khp ni v va chm ln nhau.

ni chung l tht kh  theo di ddataa flow ca ng dng. :)

# Gii php: lung d liu tuyn tnh (unidirectional data flow)
v vy Facebook  quyt nh th mt kin trc khc, sao cho lung d liu ch chy theo mt hng, khi bn mung thm mt d liu mi, lung d liu chy li t u.  ' 
![](6.png)
iu ny thc s rt hay... nhng c l n khng thc s n gin nh s  trn.

nt khi bn  hiu Flux, biu  ny mi thc s r rng, vn   y l nu bn xem qua docs mi nht ca Flux, ti khng ngh rng biu  ny c th gip bn hiu c, biu  ch gip bn c c ci nhn ton cnh v h thng trc khi bn i vo tn hiu k hn tng thnh phn ca n.

What helped me understand Flux better wasnt a diagram like this, but instead thinking of the system in terms of different characters working together as a team to achieve a goal. So I want to introduce you to the cast of characters that I have in my head.

Hy tng tng cc thnh phn h thng nh cc nhn vt lm vc chung vi nhau  t  c  mt mc tiu chung. by gi ti mun gii thiu vi cc bn nhng nhn vt ti  hnh dung ra. 

# gii thi cc nhn vt 

ti s gii thiu cc nhn vt v h tng tc vi nhau nh th no.

## Action creator (ng nh my)
nhn vt u tin ca chng ta chnh l action creator, ngi chu trch nhim cho sinh ra tt c cc action ca h thng, ni m tt c c thay i v cc tng tc phi i qua. Bt c khi no bn mun thay i trng thi hc thay di view bn phi goi n ng ny. 

![](7.png)
ti ngh v  action creator nh ng nh my fax. mi khi bn mun  gi tin i  b phi n gp ng ny v bo ng  ni  dung mun g, ngi nh my s  nh dng li tin nhn sao cho ton b phn cn li ca h thng c th  h u  c .

ng nh my s to mt action bao gm  m hiu (type) v mt khi  d liu (payload). m hiu s l mooth trong s m hiu m h thng  ngm nh vi nhau t trc kiu nh MESSAGE_CREATE hay MESSAGE_READ.

Actions creator cn c mt hiu ng ph na, ng ny bit tt c cc kiu  action . mt dev mi vo tram ch cn m file acrion creator ln l bit tt c cc action ca h thng . 

Once it has created the action message, the action creator passes that action off to the dispatcher.

khi ng ny nh my xong, thng ip s c truyn n  Dispatcher. 

## Dispatcher  (thng a th)
Thc cht Dispatcher bao gm mt lot  cc ng k callback. ging nh mng a th, ng ny gi mt danh sch cc kho c th nhn tin tu action creator. v chuyn thng ip n .  

![](8.png)
ng ny lm vic mt cch khng ng b
 n tt c cc kho trong h thng, nu bn mun thng ip chir c  gi  khi lm xong vic g khcm bn c th  qun l dispatcher thc hin chc nng ny vi hm waitFor().

Dispatcher ca Flux khc vi dispatcher ca cc kin trc khc  ch, thng ip c gi  ti tt c cc  kho  khng phn bit action type l g. iu  c ngha tt c cc store u nhn c  c cc thng ip v phi t mnh lc xem mnh cn nghe thng thng ip no.

## The store (kho)
Tip theo l store, store l ni gi tt c cc trng thi ca ng dng
, tt c cc trng thi thay i logic u nm trong kho.

Store nh mt nhn vin kim sot kho vy, tt c cc trng thi phi thay i thng qua mt c th, bn khng th trc tip yu cu tahy i trng thi c, i tng store s khng c setters m chi c getters thi.  thay di trng thi bn cn theo ng trnh t... bn cn to ra mt action bng acrion creator v gi i thng qua dispatcher.

Nh   cp  trn, nu Store  ng k vi dispatcher, mi action s c n n. bn trong mi store trng l mt biu thc switch phn loi acrion u vo thng qua type v thc hin logic tng ng. nu action thuc loi store quan tm n s x l action v tr li mt trng thi tip theo ca ng ng. nu khng store s b qua action ny.

Mt khi store  cp nht trng thi, n s tung ra mt s kin change, thng bo cho controller view rng trng thi  b thay i cn update li.

## controller view v view

View chnh l giao din ngi dng, view c dng da trn trng thi, th hin trng thi ti nhi dng cng nh nhn tng tc ca ngi dng  to ra trng thi mi.

![](9.png)

View ch l giao din, n khng h bit g v logic ca ng dng, n ch nhn ly data v dng thnh giao din ng dng c h hiu c (bng HTML). 

Controller view lm nhim v qun l gia store v view. N nhn ly thng bao thay i trng thi t store. tp hp nhng thay i v truyn trng thi mi cho tt c nhng view n qun l. 

So lets take a look at how all of these characters work together.

Hy xem qua mi cc thnh phn lm vic vi nhau th no nh.

# cc thnh phn tng tc nh th no

## Setup

u tin l phn setup: ng ng c khi to, vic vy ch dn ra mt ln.

1. Store thng bo cho dispatcher mi khi c trng thi thay i

![](10/png)

2.ri controller views yu cu trng thi mi nht t store.

3. Khi store gi trng thi cho controller views, controller views gi trng thi ti cc view  dng giao din.

![](11.png)

![](12.png)

s kin t hnh t tng tc s c bn ra.

![](13.png)

![](14.png)

2. action creator to ra action da trn tng tc v g ti dispatcher.

![](15.png)

![](16.png)

Post.raw:
---
title: Flux l ci qui g nh
date: 2016-08-07 23:53:52
tags:
	- Flux
	- javascript
	- design pattern
	- framework
	- fontend
categories:
	- cng ngh	
---
{% asset_img "1.png" %}

Flux l mt kin trc cho cho font-end do Faceebook pht trin vi mc ch gii quyt chnh nhng vn  Facebook gp phi.  Kin trc ny gip qun l cc hnh ng (actions)  trng thi (state) ca ng dng mt cch ng b v d tin on (predicable), nht l vi cc ng dng c cu trc phc tp nh Facebook. bi vit ny s gii thiu v Flux cng nh cch hot ng ca n.  

<!--more-->
# Vn  m Flux gii quyt

trc tin, ta s im qua mt s vn  m Flux gii quyt. Flux l mt mu thit k  x l d liu cho ng dng, Flux v React c phat trin song song bi Facebook. V cng c thit k  s dng chung vi nhau, d vy bn hon ton c th dng Flux m khng cn n React. N c pht trin  gii qut chnh nhng vn  m Facebook ng gp phi.

![](./2.png)
Mt trong nhng vn   chnh l bug trong phn thng bo (notification). Khi bn ng nhp vo Facebook bn s nhn thy cc thng bo trn biu tng tin nhn. ri bn click vo biu tng tin nhn nhng li khng c tin nhn mi no c thng bo tin nhn mbt i, bn lt linh tinh mt lt v li c thng bo tin nhn, nhng khi click vo vn ch c tin no mi c. ch l mt vng lp ca bug m khng th gi qut vi kin trc MVC thng thng.

![](3.png)
Khng ch mt vng lp bug, m cn mt ng lp xay ra vi Facebook team khi h c fix li ny v ri mt bg mi li xut hin. mt cuc chin khng c hi kt ga dev team v bug.

vy nn Facebook mun tm cch  thot khi ci vng lun qun ny. h khng ch mun fix bux mt ln m h mun mt h thng d tin on hn v c th dm bo rng vn  c gii quyt mt cch trit .

# Bn cht ca vn 

bn cht ca vn  chnh l cch m lung d liu chy qua ng dng. 

Note: y l nhng th m ti thy c t bn rt gn m h  trnh by, nhng ti tin chc reawng kin trc thc th s khc i cht.

![](4.png)
Ta c mt vi model chu trch nhim nm gi dt ton b d liu ca ng dng  tng view  hin th ra.

bi v ngi dng tng tc thng qua view, tng view i khi cn cp nht vo models thng qua  input ca ngi dng. i khi model cng cn phi cp nht cc model khc.

quan trng nht, i khi mt vi hnh ng s ko theo mt lot cc thay i trng thi khc. c th hnh dung n nh chi bng bn tht kh  n c i ri ca bng trn bn, cng c th ra ngoi.

![](5.png)
trn thc t nhng thay i ny c th xy ra khng ng b, mt thay i c th ko theo vi thy i khc m khng nht thit xy ra ng thi. Ging nh ta nm mt r bng bn cho 2 ngi chi vy bng by khp ni v va chm ln nhau.

ni chung l tht kh  theo di ddataa flow ca ng dng. :)

# Gii php: lung d liu tuyn tnh (unidirectional data flow)
v vy Facebook  quyt nh th mt kin trc khc, sao cho lung d liu ch chy theo mt hng, khi bn mung thm mt d liu mi, lung d liu chy li t u.  ' 
![](6.png)
iu ny thc s rt hay... nhng c l n khng thc s n gin nh s  trn.

nt khi bn  hiu Flux, biu  ny mi thc s r rng, vn   y l nu bn xem qua docs mi nht ca Flux, ti khng ngh rng biu  ny c th gip bn hiu c, biu  ch gip bn c c ci nhn ton cnh v h thng trc khi bn i vo tn hiu k hn tng thnh phn ca n.

What helped me understand Flux better wasnt a diagram like this, but instead thinking of the system in terms of different characters working together as a team to achieve a goal. So I want to introduce you to the cast of characters that I have in my head.

Hy tng tng cc thnh phn h thng nh cc nhn vt lm vc chung vi nhau  t  c  mt mc tiu chung. by gi ti mun gii thiu vi cc bn nhng nhn vt ti  hnh dung ra. 

# gii thi cc nhn vt 

ti s gii thiu cc nhn vt v h tng tc vi nhau nh th no.

## Action creator (ng nh my)
nhn vt u tin ca chng ta chnh l action creator, ngi chu trch nhim cho sinh ra tt c cc action ca h thng, ni m tt c c thay i v cc tng tc phi i qua. Bt c khi no bn mun thay i trng thi hc thay di view bn phi goi n ng ny. 

![](7.png)
ti ngh v  action creator nh ng nh my fax. mi khi bn mun  gi tin i  b phi n gp ng ny v bo ng  ni  dung mun g, ngi nh my s  nh dng li tin nhn sao cho ton b phn cn li ca h thng c th  h u  c .

ng nh my s to mt action bao gm  m hiu (type) v mt khi  d liu (payload). m hiu s l mooth trong s m hiu m h thng  ngm nh vi nhau t trc kiu nh MESSAGE_CREATE hay MESSAGE_READ.

Actions creator cn c mt hiu ng ph na, ng ny bit tt c cc kiu  action . mt dev mi vo tram ch cn m file acrion creator ln l bit tt c cc action ca h thng . 

Once it has created the action message, the action creator passes that action off to the dispatcher.

khi ng ny nh my xong, thng ip s c truyn n  Dispatcher. 

## Dispatcher  (thng a th)
Thc cht Dispatcher bao gm mt lot  cc ng k callback. ging nh mng a th, ng ny gi mt danh sch cc kho c th nhn tin tu action creator. v chuyn thng ip n .  

![](8.png)
ng ny lm vic mt cch khng ng b
 n tt c cc kho trong h thng, nu bn mun thng ip chir c  gi  khi lm xong vic g khcm bn c th  qun l dispatcher thc hin chc nng ny vi hm waitFor().

Dispatcher ca Flux khc vi dispatcher ca cc kin trc khc  ch, thng ip c gi  ti tt c cc  kho  khng phn bit action type l g. iu  c ngha tt c cc store u nhn c  c cc thng ip v phi t mnh lc xem mnh cn nghe thng thng ip no.

## The store (kho)
Tip theo l store, store l ni gi tt c cc trng thi ca ng dng
, tt c cc trng thi thay i logic u nm trong kho.

Store nh mt nhn vin kim sot kho vy, tt c cc trng thi phi thay i thng qua mt c th, bn khng th trc tip yu cu tahy i trng thi c, i tng store s khng c setters m chi c getters thi.  thay di trng thi bn cn theo ng trnh t... bn cn to ra mt action bng acrion creator v gi i thng qua dispatcher.

Nh   cp  trn, nu Store  ng k vi dispatcher, mi action s c n n. bn trong mi store trng l mt biu thc switch phn loi acrion u vo thng qua type v thc hin logic tng ng. nu action thuc loi store quan tm n s x l action v tr li mt trng thi tip theo ca ng ng. nu khng store s b qua action ny.

Mt khi store  cp nht trng thi, n s tung ra mt s kin change, thng bo cho controller view rng trng thi  b thay i cn update li.

## controller view v view

View chnh l giao din ngi dng, view c dng da trn trng thi, th hin trng thi ti nhi dng cng nh nhn tng tc ca ngi dng  to ra trng thi mi.

![](9.png)

View ch l giao din, n khng h bit g v logic ca ng dng, n ch nhn ly data v dng thnh giao din ng dng c h hiu c (bng HTML). 

Controller view lm nhim v qun l gia store v view. N nhn ly thng bao thay i trng thi t store. tp hp nhng thay i v truyn trng thi mi cho tt c nhng view n qun l. 

So lets take a look at how all of these characters work together.

Hy xem qua mi cc thnh phn lm vic vi nhau th no nh.

# cc thnh phn tng tc nh th no

## Setup

u tin l phn setup: ng ng c khi to, vic vy ch dn ra mt ln.

1. Store thng bo cho dispatcher mi khi c trng thi thay i

![](10/png)

2.ri controller views yu cu trng thi mi nht t store.

3. Khi store gi trng thi cho controller views, controller views gi trng thi ti cc view  dng giao din.

![](11.png)

4. The controller views also ask the stores to keep them notified when state changes.

4. Controller views cng ng k nhn thng bo khi trng thi thay i.

![](12.png)

## Lung d liu

Khi setup xong, ng dng s sn sng  nhn tng tc ca ngi dng, v mi khi c tng tc t ngi dng lung d liu s bt y chy.

s kin t hnh t tng tc s c bn ra.

![](13.png)

1. view thng bo cho action creator chun b mt action mi.

![](14.png)

2. action creator to ra action da trn tng tc v g ti dispatcher.

![](15.png)

3. Dispatcher gii action ti store theo mt hng di (FIFO), mi store u c thng bo vi mi action ri store s qut nh c x l action hay khng, v thay i trng thi da vo .

![](16.png)

4. Mt khi trnh thi  thay i, store gi thng bo n cc controllers  ng k vi n.

5. nhng controller views ny yu cu ly state mi t store v tin hnh cp nht trng thi mi.

![](17.png)

Hy vng bi vit ny gip bn hiu hn v Flux!

Nh cp trn, nu Store ng k vi dispatcher, mi action s c n n. bn trong mi store trng l mt biu thc switch phn loi acrion u vo thng qua type v thc hin logic tng ng. nu action thuc loi store quan tm n s x l action v tr li mt trng thi tip theo ca ng ng. nu khng store s b qua action ny.

Mt khi store cp nht trng thi, n s tung ra mt s kin change, thng bo cho controller view rng trng thi b thay i cn update li.

controller view v view

View chnh l giao din ngi dng, view c dng da trn trng thi, th hin trng thi ti nhi dng cng nh nhn tng tc ca ngi dng to ra trng thi mi.

View ch l giao din, n khng h bit g v logic ca ng dng, n ch nhn ly data v dng thnh giao din ng dng c h hiu c (bng HTML).

Controller view lm nhim v qun l gia store v view. N nhn ly thng bao thay i trng thi t store. tp hp nhng thay i v truyn trng thi mi cho tt c nhng view n qun l.

So lets take a look at how all of these characters work together.

Hy xem qua mi cc thnh phn lm vic vi nhau th no nh.

cc thnh phn tng tc nh th no

Setup

u tin l phn setup: ng ng c khi to, vic vy ch dn ra mt ln.

  1. Store thng bo cho dispatcher mi khi c trng thi thay i

2.ri controller views yu cu trng thi mi nht t store.

  1. Khi store gi trng thi cho controller views, controller views gi trng thi ti cc view dng giao din.

  1. The controller views also ask the stores to keep them notified when state changes.

  2. Controller views cng ng k nhn thng bo khi trng thi thay i.

Lung d liu

Khi setup xong, ng dng s sn sng nhn tng tc ca ngi dng, v mi khi c tng tc t ngi dng lung d liu s bt y chy.

s kin t hnh t tng tc s c bn ra.

  1. view thng bo cho action creator chun b mt action mi.

  1. action creator to ra action da trn tng tc v g ti dispatcher.

  1. Dispatcher gii action ti store theo mt hng di (FIFO), mi store u c thng bo vi mi action ri store s qut nh c x l action hay khng, v thay i trng thi da vo .

  1. Mt khi trnh thi thay i, store gi thng bo n cc controllers ng k vi n.

  2. nhng controller views ny yu cu ly state mi t store v tin hnh cp nht trng thi mi.

Hy vng bi vit ny gip bn hiu hn v Flux!

Post.title: React + Redux + Rxjs = AMAZING!
Post.content:
Vi cc ng dng front-end ni chung v ng dng dn trang ni ring MVC hay MVP xem ra khng qun l trng thi nht l cc ng dng c trng thi phc tp hm no rnh mnh s vit mt bi v MVC - client-side , cn hm nay chng ta s cp n React. Mt trong nhng iu mnh thy th v nht vi React chnh l h sinh thi xung quanh n vi s lng v cht lng ngy cng tng ln, c l bi v React gi ng ch nga ca cc dev nn nhn c s ng h v ng gp rt ln ca cng ng m ngun m trn ton th gii. Bi vit ny s gii thiu mt b combo rt mnh m vi cc font-end developer l React + Redux + ReactiveX.

M u

D lm ng dng javascript nht ng dng front-end th s khng th trnh khi cc tc v bt ng b nh i input ngi dng, ajax, animation tuy React + Redux rt tuyt vi nhng c v vn cha x l cc tc v bt ng b mt cch ng b, lp vo khong trng ny rt nhiu dev front-end chn ReactiveX c th l redux-rx, khng bit th vin ny c im g hp n nh?.

u tin c l ta s tm hiu mt cht v ReactiveX, ReactiveX l mt th vin a nn tng cung cp mt lot tin ch cho php lp trnh vin d dng hn trng vic x l cc tc v bt ng b phc tp m v m bo code sch, d qu l cc trng thi v nm ton qun iu khin lung d liu ng x l.

ReactiveX is a combination of the best ideas from
the Observer pattern, the Iterator pattern, and functional programming

http://reactivex.io

Mt cch ngn gn m ni th nhng g Jquery lm vi DOM rxjs lm tng t vi data, vi mt lot cc ton t x l cc lung d liu mt cch n gin v ch ng.

redux-observable

redux-observable l mt cng c gip tch hp nhng tnh nng tuyt vi ca reactiveX vi redux ni mt cch n gin th ta s c th dispatch mt observable.

ci th c li g? thc s l nhiu ci li hn bn ngh dy, v d nh:

  • c th s dng cc ton t ca rxjs thao tc trn tp d liu.
  • cho php hy action mt cch d dng.
  • x l li d dng v trit .
  • thao tc d dng vi cc tc v bt ng b (tt nhin ri)
  • v cn nhiu na,

tnh nng u tin l ta c th dispatch mt observable:

mt cch na hy action l dng hm takeUntil, tc l acion s vn tip tc tc hin cho n khi nhn c mt action thng bo ngng li.

Th v ng khng no! y mi l bt u thi, middware mi l ci mnh mun nhc n. chc hn mi ngi cng khng cn xa l vi redux middware na, middware l ni chuyn tip action t action creator n reducers.

khi c mt observable, vi middleware ta c th lm rt nhiu th hhay ho,

y l v d hon chnh vic s dng middware:

JS Bin on jsbin.com

vi epicMiddleware mi tc v bt ng b tr nn d dng hn rt nhiu, ta c th lm tun t hoc mt song song mt nhm action m vn d dng qun l c thng thi ca ng dng. qu tuyt vi.

Post.title: REDUX tui tr ti cao
Post._content:
{% asset_img redux-1.png "redux" %}

C mt u cn lm bn "bi ri" hn c Flux chnh l phn bit Flux vi Redux, mt pattern pht ly cm hng t Flux. Bi vit ny s ch ra nhng im khc bit gia hi pattern ny.

nu bn cha c bi gii thiu v Flux, bn nn c qua trc khi c bi vit ny.

<!--more-->

Redux c to ra  gii qut cc vn  ging nh Flux cng thm mt s th khc. 

cng nh Flux, Redux sinh ra  qun l cc trng thi ca ng dng, lm cho cc trng thi tr nn d tin on hn (predictable). Nu bn mun thay i trn thi bn buc phi phun ra mt action. Bn s khng th thay i thng thi mt cch trc tip v phn lu thng thi (Store) ch c getter khng c setters. v c bn th Redux v Flux thc s rt ging nhau.

So why a different pattern? Redux creator Dan Abramov saw an opportunity to improve on Flux. He wanted better developer tools. He saw that if you moved a couple of things around, you could make better developer tools possible, but still have the same predictability that Flux gives you.

Vy im khc bit  y l g? tc gi ca Redux @Dan Abramov  nhn thy nhng tim nng ca Flux, ng y c mt b cng c pht trin tt hn, ng thy rng nu thay i mt s th, bn c th c mt cng c hon ho hn trong khi vn c c y  cc tnh nng m Flux em li.

@Dan Abramov mun hot reloading (code v nhn thy thay i lun) v time travel debugging (). Nhng c mt s vn  khin cho developer tools kh lm vic vi Flux.

> **Vn  1: code ca Store khng th reload nu khng xa trng thi**

Trong Flux, Strore bao gm 2 th:

1. Trng thi lm thay thay i logic 
2. Trng thi hin ti

Cha c 2 th trong cng mt i tng chnh l cha kha cho hot reloading. Khi bn ti li i tng Store  kt qu m trng thai thay i logic to ra, bn mt trng thi c g trong Strore, thm na, bn  ng k mt s kin  buc Store lu trng thi ca phn cn li ca h thng.

![](2.png)

**Gii php**

Tch bit hai chc nng, mt i tng s lu trng thi, i tng ny khng c reload. Mt i tng khc bn gm tt c cc trng thi thai i logic, i tng ny c th c reload n khng h gi trng thi no c.

> **Vn  2: Trng thi c th b ghi  bi mi mt action**

In time travel debugging, you keep track of each version of a state object. That way, you can go back to an earlier state.

Each time the state is changed, you need to add the old state to an array of previous state objects. But because of the way JavaScript works, simply adding the variable to the array wont work. This doesnt create a snapshot of the object, it just creates a new pointer to the same object.

To make it work, each version needs to be an entirely separate object so that you arent accidentally changing past versions.

![](4.png)

**Solution**
When an action comes in to the store, dont handle it by changing the state. Instead, copy the state and make changes to the copy.

![](5.png)

> **Problem 3: There arent good places for third-party plugins to jump in**

When youre making developer tools, you need to be able to write them generically. A user should be able to just drop the tool in without having to custom fit their own code around it.

For this to work, you need extension points places where the code expects to have things added to it.

An example is logging. Lets say you want to console.log() every action as it comes in, and then console.log() the state that results from it. In Flux, youd have to subscribe to the dispatchers updates and to updates from each store. But thats custom code, not something a third-party module can easily do.

![](6.png)

**Solution**
Make it easy to wrap parts of the system in other objects. These other objects add their bit of functionality on top of the original. You can see these kinds of extension points in things like enhancers or higher order objects, as well as middleware.

In addition, use a tree to structure the state change logic. This makes it so the store only emits one event to notify the views that the state has changed. This event comes after the whole state tree has been processed.


![](7.png)
Note: With these problems and solutions, Im focusing on the developer tooling use case. These changes help in other use cases, too. On top of that, there are other differences between Redux and Flux. For example, Redux also reduces boilerplate and it makes it easier to reuse logic in the store. Heres a list of some other upsides to Redux.

So lets see how Redux makes these things possible.

## The new cast of characters

The new cast of characters

### Action creators

![](8.png)

Redux keeps the action creator from Flux. Whenever you want to change the state of the application, you shoot off an action. Thats the only way that the state should be changed.

As I said in the article on Flux, I think of the action creator as a telegraph operator. You go to the action creator knowing basically what message you want to send, and then the action creator formats that in a way that the rest of the system can understand.

**
Unlike Flux, action creators in Redux do not send the action to the dispatcher. Instead, they return a formatted action object.
**

### The Store

I described stores in Flux as over-controlling bureaucrats. All state changes must be made personally by a store and have to go through the action pipeline, instead of being requested directly. The store in Redux is still controlling and bureaucratic, but its a little bit different.

![](9.png)

In Flux, you can have multiple stores. Each store has its own little fiefdom, and it is in total control. It holds on to its little slice of state, and has all the logic for changing that little slice of state.

The Redux store tends to delegate more. And it has to. In Redux, there is only one store so if it did everything itself, it would be taking on too much work.

Instead, it takes care of holding on to the whole state tree. It then delegates the work of figuring out what state changes need to happen. The reducers, headed up by the root reducer, take on this task.

You might have noticed theres no dispatcher. Thats because, in a bit of a power grab, the store has also taken over dispatching.

### The reducers

When the store needs to know how an action changes the state, it asks the reducers. The root reducer takes charge and slices the state up based on the state objects keys. It passes each slice of state to the reducer that knows how to handle it.

![](10.png)

I think of the reducers as a department of white-collar workers who are a little overzealous about photocopying. They dont want to mess anything up, so they dont change the state that has been passed in to them. Instead, they make a copy and make all their changes on the copy.

This is one of the key ideas of Redux. The state object isnt manipulated directly. Instead, each slice is copied and then all of the slices are combined into a new state object.

The reducers pass their copies back to the root reducer, which pastes the copies together to form the updated state object. Then the root reducer sends the new state object back to the store, and the store makes it the new official state.

If you have a small application, you might only have one reducer making a copy of the whole state object and making its changes. Or if you have a large application, you might have a whole tree of reducers. This is another difference between Flux and Redux. In Flux, the stores arent necessarily connected to each other and they have a flat structure. In Redux, the reducers are in a heirarchy. This hierarchy can have as many levels as needed, just like the component hierarchy.

### The views: smart and dumb components

Flux has controller views and regular views. The controller views act as middle managers, managing the communication between the store and their child views.

![](11.png)

In Redux, theres a similar concept: smart and dumb components. The smart components are the managers. They follow a few more rules than the controller views, though:

	- Smart components are in charge of the actions. If a dumb component underneath them needs to trigger an action, the smart component passes a function in via the props. The dumb component can then just treat that as a callback.
	- Smart components do not have their own CSS styles
	- Smart components rarely emit DOM of their own. Instead, they arrange dumb components, which handle laying out DOM elements.

Dumb components dont depend on action files directly, since all actions are passed in via props. This means that the dumb component can be reused in a different app that has different logic. They also contain the styles that they need to look reasonably good (though you can allow for custom stylingjust accept a style prop and merge it in to the default styles).

### The view layer binding

![](12.png)

To connect the store to the views, Redux needs a little help. It needs something to bind the two together. This is called the view layer binding. If youre using React, this is react-redux.

The view layer binding is kind of like the IT department for the view tree. It makes sure that all of the components can connect to the store. It also takes care of a lot of technical details so that the rest of the hierarchy doesnt have to understand them.

The view layer binding introduces three concepts:
	1. The Provider component: This is wrapped around the component tree. It makes it easy for the root components children to hook up to the store using connect().
	2. connect(): This is a function provided by react-redux. If a component wants to get state updates, it wraps itself using connect(). Then the connect function will set up all the wiring for it, using the selector.
	3. selector: This is a function that you write. It specifies what parts of the state a component needs as properties.

### The root component

![](13.png)

All React applications have root components. This is just the component at the top level of the component hierarchy. But in Redux applications, this component takes on more responsibility.

The role it plays is kind of like a C-level executive. It puts all of the teams in place to tackle the work. It creates the store, telling it what reducer to use, and brings together the view layer binding and the views.

The root component is pretty hands-off after it initializes the app, though. It doesnt get caught up in the day-to-day concerns of triggering rerenders. It leaves that to the components below it, assisted by the view layer binding.


## How they all work together
Lets see how these parts work together to create a functioning app.

### The Setup

The different parts of the app need to be wired up together. This happens in setup.

1. **Get the store ready.** The root component creates the store, telling it what root reducer to use, using createStore(). This root reducer already has a team of reducers which report to it. It assembled that team of reducers using combineReducers().

![](14.png)

2. **Set up the communication between the store and the components.*** The root component wraps its subcomponents with the provider component and makes the connection between the store and the provider.

The Provider creates whats basically a network to update the components. The smart components connect to network using connect(). This ensures theyll get state updates.

![](15.png)

3. **Prepare the action callbacks.** To make it easier for dumb components to work with actions, the smart components can setup action callbacks by using bindActionCreators(). This way, they can just pass down a callback to the dumb component. The action will be automatically dispatched after it is formatted.

![](16.png)

### The data flow

Now that the application is set up, the user can start interacting with it. Lets trigger an action to see the data flow.

![](17.png)

1. The view requests an action. The action creator formats it and returns it.

![](18.png)

2. The action is either dispatched automatically (if bindActionCreators() was used in setup), or the view dispatches the action.

![](19.png)

3. The store receives the action. It sends the current state tree and the action to the root reducer.

![](20.png)

4. The root reducer cuts apart the state tree into slices. Then it passes each slice to the subreducer that knows how to deal with it.

![](21.png)

5. The subreducer copies the slice and makes changes to the copy. It returns the copy of the slice to the root reducer.

![](22.png)

6. Once all of the subreducers have returned their slice copies, the root reducer pastes all of them together to form the whole updated state tree, which it returns to the store. The store replaces the old state tree with the new one.

![](23.png)

7. The store tells the view layer binding that theres new state.

![](24.png)

8. The view layer binding asks the store to send over the new state.

![](25.png)

9. The view layer binding triggers a rerender.

![](26.png)

So thats how I think of Redux and its differences from Flux. Hope it helps!

## Kt lun

cm n v bi vit rt th v i ca **Lin Clark** v [code-cartoons.com](https://code-cartoons.com/). 

redux l mt kin trc mi cho tng view n c facebook pht trin  gii qut cc vn  c hu ca facebook khi dng MVC. t xa n nay lm vic vi font-end s c hai dng kin trc chnh:

1. **kin trc hng s kin** c ngha l s ln lt ng k cc s kin, khi c s kin th thc thi hot ng ri update view. trang nh th khng sao nu trang ln v logic phc tp th n tr thnh thm ha c vi UX v DX, u tin bn s khng th no phn bit c cc thnh phn cng nh vng i ca cc s kin, ri s ra sao nu mun thm mt tc v cho s kin no . n mt lc bn nhn li ng sn phm ca mnh v ch c mnh c th p i xy li t u. :D

Post.raw:
---
title: REDUX tui tr ti cao
date: 2016-06-28 22:15:25
tags:
	- redux
	- framework
	- javascript
	- Flux
categories:
	- cng ngh		
---
{% asset_img redux-1.png "redux" %}

C mt u cn lm bn "bi ri" hn c Flux chnh l phn bit Flux vi Redux, mt pattern pht ly cm hng t Flux. Bi vit ny s ch ra nhng im khc bit gia hi pattern ny.

nu bn cha c bi gii thiu v Flux, bn nn c qua trc khi c bi vit ny.

<!--more-->

Redux c to ra  gii qut cc vn  ging nh Flux cng thm mt s th khc. 

cng nh Flux, Redux sinh ra  qun l cc trng thi ca ng dng, lm cho cc trng thi tr nn d tin on hn (predictable). Nu bn mun thay i trn thi bn buc phi phun ra mt action. Bn s khng th thay i thng thi mt cch trc tip v phn lu thng thi (Store) ch c getter khng c setters. v c bn th Redux v Flux thc s rt ging nhau.

So why a different pattern? Redux creator Dan Abramov saw an opportunity to improve on Flux. He wanted better developer tools. He saw that if you moved a couple of things around, you could make better developer tools possible, but still have the same predictability that Flux gives you.

Vy im khc bit  y l g? tc gi ca Redux @Dan Abramov  nhn thy nhng tim nng ca Flux, ng y c mt b cng c pht trin tt hn, ng thy rng nu thay i mt s th, bn c th c mt cng c hon ho hn trong khi vn c c y  cc tnh nng m Flux em li.

@Dan Abramov mun hot reloading (code v nhn thy thay i lun) v time travel debugging (). Nhng c mt s vn  khin cho developer tools kh lm vic vi Flux.

> **Vn  1: code ca Store khng th reload nu khng xa trng thi**

Trong Flux, Strore bao gm 2 th:

1. Trng thi lm thay thay i logic 
2. Trng thi hin ti

Cha c 2 th trong cng mt i tng chnh l cha kha cho hot reloading. Khi bn ti li i tng Store  kt qu m trng thai thay i logic to ra, bn mt trng thi c g trong Strore, thm na, bn  ng k mt s kin  buc Store lu trng thi ca phn cn li ca h thng.

![](2.png)

**Gii php**

Tch bit hai chc nng, mt i tng s lu trng thi, i tng ny khng c reload. Mt i tng khc bn gm tt c cc trng thi thai i logic, i tng ny c th c reload n khng h gi trng thi no c.

> **Vn  2: Trng thi c th b ghi  bi mi mt action**

In time travel debugging, you keep track of each version of a state object. That way, you can go back to an earlier state.

Each time the state is changed, you need to add the old state to an array of previous state objects. But because of the way JavaScript works, simply adding the variable to the array wont work. This doesnt create a snapshot of the object, it just creates a new pointer to the same object.

To make it work, each version needs to be an entirely separate object so that you arent accidentally changing past versions.

![](4.png)

**Solution**
When an action comes in to the store, dont handle it by changing the state. Instead, copy the state and make changes to the copy.

![](5.png)

> **Problem 3: There arent good places for third-party plugins to jump in**

When youre making developer tools, you need to be able to write them generically. A user should be able to just drop the tool in without having to custom fit their own code around it.

For this to work, you need extension points places where the code expects to have things added to it.

An example is logging. Lets say you want to console.log() every action as it comes in, and then console.log() the state that results from it. In Flux, youd have to subscribe to the dispatchers updates and to updates from each store. But thats custom code, not something a third-party module can easily do.

![](6.png)

**Solution**
Make it easy to wrap parts of the system in other objects. These other objects add their bit of functionality on top of the original. You can see these kinds of extension points in things like enhancers or higher order objects, as well as middleware.

In addition, use a tree to structure the state change logic. This makes it so the store only emits one event to notify the views that the state has changed. This event comes after the whole state tree has been processed.


![](7.png)
Note: With these problems and solutions, Im focusing on the developer tooling use case. These changes help in other use cases, too. On top of that, there are other differences between Redux and Flux. For example, Redux also reduces boilerplate and it makes it easier to reuse logic in the store. Heres a list of some other upsides to Redux.

So lets see how Redux makes these things possible.

## The new cast of characters

The new cast of characters

### Action creators

![](8.png)

Redux keeps the action creator from Flux. Whenever you want to change the state of the application, you shoot off an action. Thats the only way that the state should be changed.

As I said in the article on Flux, I think of the action creator as a telegraph operator. You go to the action creator knowing basically what message you want to send, and then the action creator formats that in a way that the rest of the system can understand.

**
Unlike Flux, action creators in Redux do not send the action to the dispatcher. Instead, they return a formatted action object.
**

### The Store

I described stores in Flux as over-controlling bureaucrats. All state changes must be made personally by a store and have to go through the action pipeline, instead of being requested directly. The store in Redux is still controlling and bureaucratic, but its a little bit different.

![](9.png)

In Flux, you can have multiple stores. Each store has its own little fiefdom, and it is in total control. It holds on to its little slice of state, and has all the logic for changing that little slice of state.

The Redux store tends to delegate more. And it has to. In Redux, there is only one store so if it did everything itself, it would be taking on too much work.

Instead, it takes care of holding on to the whole state tree. It then delegates the work of figuring out what state changes need to happen. The reducers, headed up by the root reducer, take on this task.

You might have noticed theres no dispatcher. Thats because, in a bit of a power grab, the store has also taken over dispatching.

### The reducers

When the store needs to know how an action changes the state, it asks the reducers. The root reducer takes charge and slices the state up based on the state objects keys. It passes each slice of state to the reducer that knows how to handle it.

![](10.png)

I think of the reducers as a department of white-collar workers who are a little overzealous about photocopying. They dont want to mess anything up, so they dont change the state that has been passed in to them. Instead, they make a copy and make all their changes on the copy.

This is one of the key ideas of Redux. The state object isnt manipulated directly. Instead, each slice is copied and then all of the slices are combined into a new state object.

The reducers pass their copies back to the root reducer, which pastes the copies together to form the updated state object. Then the root reducer sends the new state object back to the store, and the store makes it the new official state.

If you have a small application, you might only have one reducer making a copy of the whole state object and making its changes. Or if you have a large application, you might have a whole tree of reducers. This is another difference between Flux and Redux. In Flux, the stores arent necessarily connected to each other and they have a flat structure. In Redux, the reducers are in a heirarchy. This hierarchy can have as many levels as needed, just like the component hierarchy.

### The views: smart and dumb components

Flux has controller views and regular views. The controller views act as middle managers, managing the communication between the store and their child views.

![](11.png)

In Redux, theres a similar concept: smart and dumb components. The smart components are the managers. They follow a few more rules than the controller views, though:

	- Smart components are in charge of the actions. If a dumb component underneath them needs to trigger an action, the smart component passes a function in via the props. The dumb component can then just treat that as a callback.
	- Smart components do not have their own CSS styles
	- Smart components rarely emit DOM of their own. Instead, they arrange dumb components, which handle laying out DOM elements.

Dumb components dont depend on action files directly, since all actions are passed in via props. This means that the dumb component can be reused in a different app that has different logic. They also contain the styles that they need to look reasonably good (though you can allow for custom stylingjust accept a style prop and merge it in to the default styles).

### The view layer binding

![](12.png)

To connect the store to the views, Redux needs a little help. It needs something to bind the two together. This is called the view layer binding. If youre using React, this is react-redux.

The view layer binding is kind of like the IT department for the view tree. It makes sure that all of the components can connect to the store. It also takes care of a lot of technical details so that the rest of the hierarchy doesnt have to understand them.

The view layer binding introduces three concepts:
	1. The Provider component: This is wrapped around the component tree. It makes it easy for the root components children to hook up to the store using connect().
	2. connect(): This is a function provided by react-redux. If a component wants to get state updates, it wraps itself using connect(). Then the connect function will set up all the wiring for it, using the selector.
	3. selector: This is a function that you write. It specifies what parts of the state a component needs as properties.

### The root component

![](13.png)

All React applications have root components. This is just the component at the top level of the component hierarchy. But in Redux applications, this component takes on more responsibility.

The role it plays is kind of like a C-level executive. It puts all of the teams in place to tackle the work. It creates the store, telling it what reducer to use, and brings together the view layer binding and the views.

The root component is pretty hands-off after it initializes the app, though. It doesnt get caught up in the day-to-day concerns of triggering rerenders. It leaves that to the components below it, assisted by the view layer binding.


## How they all work together
Lets see how these parts work together to create a functioning app.

### The Setup

The different parts of the app need to be wired up together. This happens in setup.

1. **Get the store ready.** The root component creates the store, telling it what root reducer to use, using createStore(). This root reducer already has a team of reducers which report to it. It assembled that team of reducers using combineReducers().

![](14.png)

2. **Set up the communication between the store and the components.*** The root component wraps its subcomponents with the provider component and makes the connection between the store and the provider.

The Provider creates whats basically a network to update the components. The smart components connect to network using connect(). This ensures theyll get state updates.

![](15.png)

3. **Prepare the action callbacks.** To make it easier for dumb components to work with actions, the smart components can setup action callbacks by using bindActionCreators(). This way, they can just pass down a callback to the dumb component. The action will be automatically dispatched after it is formatted.

![](16.png)

### The data flow

Now that the application is set up, the user can start interacting with it. Lets trigger an action to see the data flow.

![](17.png)

1. The view requests an action. The action creator formats it and returns it.

![](18.png)

2. The action is either dispatched automatically (if bindActionCreators() was used in setup), or the view dispatches the action.

![](19.png)

3. The store receives the action. It sends the current state tree and the action to the root reducer.

![](20.png)

4. The root reducer cuts apart the state tree into slices. Then it passes each slice to the subreducer that knows how to deal with it.

![](21.png)

5. The subreducer copies the slice and makes changes to the copy. It returns the copy of the slice to the root reducer.

![](22.png)

6. Once all of the subreducers have returned their slice copies, the root reducer pastes all of them together to form the whole updated state tree, which it returns to the store. The store replaces the old state tree with the new one.

![](23.png)

7. The store tells the view layer binding that theres new state.

![](24.png)

8. The view layer binding asks the store to send over the new state.

![](25.png)

9. The view layer binding triggers a rerender.

![](26.png)

So thats how I think of Redux and its differences from Flux. Hope it helps!
